<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_:
```c
void
MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  /* Cache 'daemon' here to avoid data races */
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = connection->daemon;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->urh);
  mhd_assert (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME));

  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  connection->urh->was_closed = true;
  connection->resuming = true;
  daemon->resuming = true;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  if ( (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc)) &&
       (! MHD_itc_activate_ (daemon->itc, "r")) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to signal resume via " \
                 "inter-thread communication channel.\n"));
#endif
  }
}
```

explanation: The MISRA Rule 17.2 prohibits direct or indirect self-calls. The fragments above are call sites or call-like macros in or reachable from MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_ that could initiate control-flow back into the same function (directly or via user callbacks), so they require investigation: the mutex-check macros expand to functions (MHD_mutex_lock_ / MHD_mutex_unlock_) and MHD_PANIC (unknown implementation); MHD_itc_activate_ expands to a write() call that may interact with user-defined I/O handlers; MHD_DLOG invokes a user-supplied custom_error_log which may call back into library code; the macro definitions shown show where calls originate. Other parts of the function do not need investigation for recursion: the simple assignments (connection->urh->was_closed = true; connection->resuming = true; daemon->resuming = true;) are plain data writes and cannot call functions; the mhd_assert macro is defined to ((void)0) so it does not call anything; MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ is a simple macro that evaluates (fd != -1) and contains no function calls. Therefore those non-call statements and no-op macros are not suspect for Rule 17.2 and need not be investigated.
